newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani Kashmiris protest at India Kashmir vote.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani Kashmiris protest at India Kashmir vote.

text.p: Public rallies and marches were held in Pakistan-controlled Azad (free) Kashmir on Saturday to protest at controversial state assembly elections in the Indian-ruled part of the disputed Himalayan region.

Indian and Pakistan troops also exchanged mortar and machinegun fire across a military control line dividing the region for the second successive day raising tension in the area, Pakistani officials said.
At least one person was killed and two were injured by Indian shelling at the Pakistan-held town of Athmuqam in Neelum Valley northeast of the state capital Muzaffarabad.
"We are forced to retaliate," a Pakistani official said.

Azad Kashmir leader Sultan Mahmood led hundreds of marchers to a U.N. military observers' office in Muzaffarabad to hand a memorandum protesting against the elections and calling for holding a U.N.-mandated plebiscite in Kashmir.
Among the placards carried by the marchers were "No to election, no to selection, yes to liberation", and "Election is no substitute for the right to self-determination".
Similar rallies were held at other towns in Azad Kashmir and in the Pakistani capital Islamabad, Kashmiri sources said.
"Kashmiris have rejected these elections (in Indian Kashmir) and will continue their struggle until freedom," Mahmood said in a speech to Muzaffarabad protesters.
Indian rules two-thirds and Pakistan the remaining third of Kashmir, over which the two countries have fought two of their three wars since their independence from Britain in 1947.
Pakistan denies Indian charges that it is training and arming Kashmiri militants fighting New Delhi rule.
Islamabad opposes elections in Indian Kashmir, saying the predominantly Moslem Kashmiris must decide whether to join Islamic Pakistan or Hindu-majority India.
